Git¶

  • To do git pull while ignoring local changes, do the following: * git reset --hard * git pull
  • Usual commands that I use to push to a git repository * git init [If not done before] * git add . [Add all the files, changes] * git commit -m "Some commit message here" * git push -u origin master
  • To access previous versions in git you can use git checkout command.
  • To see git commit history - git log
  • Usual command is git checkout commit_key
  • git --work-tree=/Users/nikhilpattisapu/test checkout 33652e3da1da6dc8de7b731edebd9e96ad5aafae -- . [To checkout the previous commit into a different folder]
  • git ls-files [Show information about files in the index and the working tree]
  • git reset --hard sha_commit_id [To rollback to a previous commit]
  • git rm -r folder_name [To remove files that were earlier tracked by git]
  • git remote -v [To view information associated with remote repositories]
  • git remote add short_name url [To add a new remote Git repository as a short name. Usually, we use origin as a short name.]
  • git remote remove short_name [To remove a remote repository]
  • git push --force origin master . Ignores everything on remote repository and forcefully pushes the local stuff on remote. * If you get error of the kind “You are not allowed to force push code to a protected branch on this project”. * Then go to the remote repository (gitlab / github). * Go to Project Settings –> Protected Branches –> Unprotect. * Re-execute the command and again protect the master branch by undoing the mentioned process”
  • git config --global http.proxy http://proxy.iiit.ac.in:8080 [To make git work behind proxy use the following (IIIT Proxy)]
  • git config --global --unset http.proxy [To unest proxy]
  • git config --global --get http.proxy [To check the proxy]
  • To include only “few specified files and directories” use the similar structure for .gitignore as described below
